column1: Nearly all known cases of Aicardi syndrome occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family (sporadic).

Children are diagnosed with Aicardi syndrome if they meet the following criteria: - Corpus callosum that is partly or completely missing - Female sex - Seizures (typically beginning as infantile spasms) - Sores on the retina (retinal lesions) or optic nerve In rare cases, one of these features may be missing (especially lack of development of the corpus callosum).
Nearly all children with this syndrome have severe learning difficulties and remain completely dependent on others.
Call your health care provider if your child has symptoms of Aicardi syndrome.
